instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2: What is SMC_PM_G2? This is a typo of SMC_PM_G2_EN When you see SMC_PM_G2, assume they meant to type SMC_PM_G2_EN.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN_L: What is PCH_INTVRMEN_L? PCH_INTVRMEN_L is a signal that stands for Internal Voltage Regulator Enable. When pulled high, this signal enables the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must be pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H..

threads.title: <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2</SIGNAL> PULSING - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
[LIST]
[*]<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>                          12.6v
[*]<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>                         20v
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>                         3.42v
[*]<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL>                            3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMMC</SIGNAL>     3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>                      3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_RTC</SIGNAL>                            3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>                   3.3
[*]<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>                3.2
[*]<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>              3.2
[*]<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K</SIGNAL>                         32.768
[*]<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>                     3.3
[/LIST]
iSSUE:
[LIST]
[*]<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2</SIGNAL>                         PULSING  (This is the issue)
[*]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>                              PULSING (This is the issue)
[/LIST]

Any suggestions if its the SMC ?

threads.title: <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2</SIGNAL> PULSING - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Test what happens in SMC bypass.
Check diode mode to ground on all big coils and other secondary supplies.

threads.title: <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2</SIGNAL> PULSING - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 74838, member: 682"]
Test what happens in SMC bypass.
Check diode mode to the ground on all big coils and other secondary supplies.
[/QUOTE]
 
I manage to find the problem and the computer works now. by using the infrared camera. Strange the capacitor was shorted for Audio and pulsing for <SIGNAL>S_0</SIGNAL> state.  Then again, I might have missed checking what state the MacBook was in, I only checked the start-up circuit. see image for the shorted cap!

threads.title: <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2</SIGNAL> PULSING - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Good job!

Please, do NOT quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.
